**James Gordon MacArthur** (December 8, 1937 – October 28, 2010) was an
American actor best known for the role of Danny "Danno" Williams, the reliable
second-in-command of the fictional Hawaiian State Police squad in the long-
running television series _[Hawaii Five-O](/wiki/Hawaii_Five-
O_\(1968_TV_series\) "Hawaii Five-O \(1968 TV series\)")_.

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=James_MacArthur&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life")]

Born in Los Angeles, MacArthur was the adopted son of playwright [Charles
MacArthur](/wiki/Charles_MacArthur "Charles MacArthur"), and his wife, actress
[Helen Hayes](/wiki/Helen_Hayes "Helen Hayes"). He grew up in [Nyack, New
York](/wiki/Nyack,_New_York "Nyack, New York"), along with the MacArthurs'
biological daughter, Mary. He was educated at [Allen-Stevenson
School](/wiki/Allen-Stevenson_School "Allen-Stevenson School") in New York,
and later at the [Solebury School](/wiki/Solebury_School "Solebury School") in
[New Hope, Pennsylvania](/wiki/New_Hope,_Pennsylvania "New Hope,
Pennsylvania"), where he starred in basketball,
[football](/wiki/American_football "American football") and baseball. In his
final year at Solebury, MacArthur played guard on the football team; captained
the basketball team; was president of his class, the student government, and
the Drama Club; rewrote the school's constitution; edited the school paper,
_The Scribe_ ; and played [Scrooge](/wiki/Ebenezer_Scrooge "Ebenezer Scrooge")
in a local presentation of _[A Christmas Carol](/wiki/A_Christmas_Carol "A
Christmas Carol")_. He also started dating a fellow student, future actress
[Joyce Bulifant](/wiki/Joyce_Bulifant "Joyce Bulifant"); they were married in
November 1958 and divorced nine years later.

MacArthur grew up around the greatest literary and theatrical talent of the
time. [Lillian Gish](/wiki/Lillian_Gish "Lillian Gish") was his godmother, and
his family's guests included [Ben Hecht](/wiki/Ben_Hecht "Ben Hecht"), [Harpo
Marx](/wiki/Harpo_Marx "Harpo Marx"), [Robert Benchley](/wiki/Robert_Benchley
"Robert Benchley"), [Beatrice Lillie](/wiki/Beatrice_Lillie "Beatrice
Lillie"), [John Barrymore](/wiki/John_Barrymore "John Barrymore") and [John
Steinbeck](/wiki/John_Steinbeck "John Steinbeck"). His first
[radio](/wiki/Old-time_radio "Old-time radio") role was on the _[Theatre Guild
on the Air](/wiki/The_United_States_Steel_Hour "The United States Steel
Hour")_ , in 1948. _Theatre Guild on the Air_ was the premier radio program of
its day, producing one-hour plays that were performed in front of a live
audience of 800. Helen Hayes accepted a role in one of the plays, which also
had a small role for a child. Her son was asked if he would like to do it, and
he agreed.

## Acting
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=James_MacArthur&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Acting career")]

MacArthur made his stage debut at [Olney, Maryland](/wiki/Olney,_Maryland
"Olney, Maryland") in 1949, with a two-week stint in _[The Corn Is
Green](/wiki/The_Corn_Is_Green "The Corn Is Green")_. His sister Mary was in
the play and telephoned their mother to request that James go to Olney to be
in it with her. The following summer, he repeated the role at [Dennis,
Massachusetts](/wiki/Dennis,_Massachusetts "Dennis, Massachusetts"), and his
theatrical career was underway. In 1954, he played John Day in _[Life with
Father](/wiki/Life_with_Father "Life with Father")_ with [Howard
Lindsay](/wiki/Howard_Lindsay "Howard Lindsay") and [Dorothy
Stickney](/wiki/Dorothy_Stickney "Dorothy Stickney"). He became involved in
important [Broadway](/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre") productions
only after receiving his training in [summer stock
theatre](/wiki/Summer_stock_theatre "Summer stock theatre").

MacArthur also worked as a set painter, lighting director, and chief of the
parking lot. During a Helen Hayes festival at the Falmouth Playhouse on [Cape
Cod](/wiki/Cape_Cod "Cape Cod"), he had a few walk-on parts. He also helped
the theatre electrician, and grew so interested that he was allowed to stay on
after his mother's plays had ended. As a result, he lit the show for [Barbara
Bel Geddes](/wiki/Barbara_Bel_Geddes "Barbara Bel Geddes") in _The Little Hut_
and for [Gloria Vanderbilt](/wiki/Gloria_Vanderbilt "Gloria Vanderbilt") in
_The Swan_. When he visited Paris with his mother as a member of _[The Skin of
Our Teeth](/wiki/The_Skin_of_Our_Teeth "The Skin of Our Teeth")_ company, he
was in charge of making thunder backstage with a sheet of metal.

At the age of 18, he played Hal Ditmar in the television play, _Deal a Blow_ ,
directed by [John Frankenheimer](/wiki/John_Frankenheimer "John
Frankenheimer") and starring [Macdonald Carey](/wiki/Macdonald_Carey
"Macdonald Carey"), [Phyllis Thaxter](/wiki/Phyllis_Thaxter "Phyllis
Thaxter"), and [Edward Arnold](/wiki/Edward_Arnold_\(actor\) "Edward Arnold
\(actor\)"). In 1956, Frankenheimer directed the movie version of the play,
which was renamed _[The Young Stranger](/wiki/The_Young_Stranger "The Young
Stranger")_ , with MacArthur again in the starring role. Again, his
performance was critically acclaimed, earning him a nomination for Most
Promising Newcomer at the 1958
[BAFTA](/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts "British Academy of
Film and Television Arts") awards.[1] He made _[The Light in the
Forest](/wiki/The_Light_in_the_Forest_\(film\) "The Light in the Forest
\(film\)")_ and _[Third Man on the Mountain](/wiki/Third_Man_on_the_Mountain
"Third Man on the Mountain")_ , for [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt
Disney"), during summer breaks from [Harvard
University](/wiki/Harvard_University "Harvard University"), where he was
studying history.

Deciding to make acting his full-time career, he left Harvard in his second
year to make two more Disney movies,
_[Kidnapped](/wiki/Kidnapped_\(1960_film\) "Kidnapped \(1960 film\)")_ and
_[Swiss Family Robinson](/wiki/Swiss_Family_Robinson_\(1960_film\) "Swiss
Family Robinson \(1960 film\)")_.

MacArthur made his Broadway debut in 1960, playing opposite [Jane
Fonda](/wiki/Jane_Fonda "Jane Fonda") in _Invitation to a March_ , for which
he received a [Theatre World Award](/wiki/Theatre_World_Award "Theatre World
Award"). Although he never returned to Broadway, he remained active in
theatre, appearing in such productions as _[Under the Yum Yum
Tree](/wiki/Under_the_Yum_Yum_Tree "Under the Yum Yum Tree")_ , _[The Moon Is
Blue](/wiki/The_Moon_Is_Blue "The Moon Is Blue")_ , _John Loves Mary_ (with
his then wife, Joyce Bulifant), _[Barefoot in the
Park](/wiki/Barefoot_in_the_Park "Barefoot in the Park")_ , and _[Murder at
the Howard Johnson's](/wiki/Murder_at_the_Howard_Johnson%27s "Murder at the
Howard Johnson's")_. He also released several records in the early 1960s,[2]
scoring two minor hits with "(The Story of) The In-Between Years" and "The Ten
Commandments of Love", both of which peaked at number 94 in the _Billboard_
Hot 100.

He then went on to roles in movies including _[The
Interns](/wiki/The_Interns_\(film\) "The Interns \(film\)")_ , _[Spencer's
Mountain](/wiki/Spencer%27s_Mountain "Spencer's Mountain")_, _[The Truth About
Spring](/wiki/The_Truth_About_Spring "The Truth About Spring")_ , and _[Cry of
Battle](/wiki/Cry_of_Battle "Cry of Battle")_ , as well as _[The Love-
Ins](/wiki/The_Love-Ins "The Love-Ins")_ and _The Angry Breed_. On the set of
_The Angry Breed_ , in 1968, MacArthur met [Melody
Patterson](/wiki/Melody_Patterson "Melody Patterson"), who was to become his
second wife. They were married on the Hawaiian Island of [Kauai](/wiki/Kauai
"Kauai") in July 1970, and divorced five years later. In 1963, he was
nominated for the "Top New Male Personality" category of the Golden Laurel
Awards.[3]

Between movie and theatre roles, MacArthur was also in demand for television
guest appearances, which included roles in _[Studio
One](/wiki/Westinghouse_Studio_One "Westinghouse Studio One")_ , _[GE
Theatre](/wiki/General_Electric_Theater "General Electric Theater")_ , _[Bus
Stop](/wiki/Bus_Stop_\(play\) "Bus Stop \(play\)")_ the play, _[Bus
Stop](/wiki/Bus_Stop_\(TV_series\) "Bus Stop \(TV series\)")_ the television
series, _[Bonanza](/wiki/Bonanza "Bonanza")_ , _[Gunsmoke](/wiki/Gunsmoke
"Gunsmoke")_ , _[Wagon Train](/wiki/Wagon_Train "Wagon Train")_ , _[The
Eleventh Hour](/wiki/The_Eleventh_Hour_\(U.S._TV_series\) "The Eleventh Hour
\(U.S. TV series\)")_ , _[The Great
Adventure](/wiki/The_Great_Adventure_\(U.S._TV_series\) "The Great Adventure
\(U.S. TV series\)")_ , _[The Alfred Hitchcock
Hour](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock_Presents "Alfred Hitchcock Presents")_ ,
_[Combat!](/wiki/Combat! "Combat!")_ , and _[The
Virginian](/wiki/The_Virginian_\(TV_series\) "The Virginian \(TV series\)")_.

In 1966, he guest-starred as Lt. Harley Wilson in "The Outsider", episode 20
in the second season of _[Twelve O'Clock High](/wiki/Twelve_O%27Clock_High
"Twelve O'Clock High")_ (TV series). He co-starred with his mother Helen Hayes
in the 1968 episode "The Pride of the Lioness" on the
_[Tarzan](/wiki/Tarzan_\(1966_TV_series\) "Tarzan \(1966 TV series\)")_
television series. MacArthur also gave a particularly chilling performance as
baby-faced opium dealer Johnny Lubin in _[The
Untouchables](/wiki/The_Untouchables_\(1959_TV_series\) "The Untouchables
\(1959 TV series\)")_ episode, "Death For Sale".

Though many of his movie roles were not starring roles, and some were quite
brief, they were usually pivotal to the plot. His role in _[The Bedford
Incident](/wiki/The_Bedford_Incident "The Bedford Incident")_ was that of a
young [ensign](/wiki/Ensign_\(rank\) "Ensign \(rank\)") who became so rattled
by the needling of his captain ([Richard Widmark](/wiki/Richard_Widmark
"Richard Widmark")), that he accidentally fired an [ASROC](/wiki/Anti-
submarine_missile "Anti-submarine missile") at a Soviet submarine, thus
creating a nuclear incident when the submarine returned fire, resulting in the
destruction of both vessels.

In _[Battle of the Bulge](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Bulge_\(film\) "Battle of the
Bulge \(film\)")_ , he again played the role of a young and inexperienced
officer. However, this time, the officer found courage and a sense of
responsibility. His brief but memorable appearance in the [Clint
Eastwood](/wiki/Clint_Eastwood "Clint Eastwood") movie, _[Hang'Em
High](/wiki/Hang_%27Em_High "Hang 'Em High")_ eventually led to his role as
Dan Williams in _[Hawaii Five-O](/wiki/Hawaii_Five-O_\(1968_TV_series\)
"Hawaii Five-O \(1968 TV series\)")_ , popularizing the
[catchphrase](/wiki/Catchphrase "Catchphrase") "Book 'em, Danno".

## _Hawaii Five-
O_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=James_MacArthur&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Hawaii Five-O")]

In 1967, [Leonard Freeman](/wiki/Leonard_Freeman "Leonard Freeman"), the
producer and co-writer of _Hang 'Em High_, made the pilot for a new television
police series, _[Hawaii Five-O](/wiki/Hawaii_Five-O_\(1968_TV_series\) "Hawaii
Five-O \(1968 TV series\)")_. Before it went to air, the pilot was well
received by test audiences, except for some dislike of the actor playing Dan
Williams.

Freeman remembered MacArthur's portrayal of the traveling preacher in _Hang
'Em High_ – MacArthur had come on the set and done the scene in one take. He
called MacArthur and offered him the role of Dan Williams.

The show was popularized by its opening sequence and theme music and location
filming in Hawaii. It was not in the top 30 in ratings until its second
season, when it was rated number 19. For the next five seasons, the show's
ratings were always in the top 10, topped by its number-three rating and 25.2
share in 1972–73.

Many episodes ended with Hawaii Five-O chief Steve McGarrett ([Jack
Lord](/wiki/Jack_Lord "Jack Lord")) instructing Williams (MacArthur) to "Book
'em, Danno!" (sometimes followed by stating a charge such as "murder one"),
which became a well-known catch phrase in popular culture. _Hawaii Five-O_ was
the longest-running TV crime drama until it was finally surpassed by _[Law&
Order](/wiki/Law_%26_Order "Law & Order")_ in 2003.

MacArthur has said that one of his favorite episodes was "Retire in Sunny
Hawaii Forever" (1975), which starred his mother, Helen Hayes. She played
Danno's Aunt Clara, who visits Hawaii and helps the detectives solve a
murder.[4]

_Hawaii Five-O_ ran for 12 years – 11 with MacArthur. Leaving the show at the
end of its 11th season, MacArthur returned to the theatre, appearing in _The
Lunch Hour_ with [Cybill Shepherd](/wiki/Cybill_Shepherd "Cybill Shepherd").

## After _Hawaii Five-
O_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=James_MacArthur&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: After Hawaii Five-O")]

He appeared in _A Bedfull of Foreigners_ in Chicago in 1984, and in Michigan
in 1985. He followed this with _The Hasty Heart_ , before taking a year out of
show business. In 1987, he returned to the stage in _The Foreigner_ , then
played Mortimer in the national tour of _Arsenic and Old Lace_ with [Jean
Stapleton](/wiki/Jean_Stapleton "Jean Stapleton"), [Marion
Ross](/wiki/Marion_Ross "Marion Ross"), and [Larry Storch](/wiki/Larry_Storch
"Larry Storch"). In 1989, he followed another stint in _The Foreigner_ with
_Love Letters_ , and in 1990–1991, _A Bedfull of Foreigners_ , this time in
Las Vegas.

After leaving _Hawaii Five-O_ , McArthur guest-starred on such television
shows as _[Murder, She Wrote](/wiki/Murder,_She_Wrote "Murder, She Wrote")_ ,
_[The Love Boat](/wiki/The_Love_Boat "The Love Boat")_ , _[Fantasy
Island](/wiki/Fantasy_Island "Fantasy Island")_ , and _[Vega$](/wiki/Vega$
"Vega$")_ , as well as in the miniseries _Alcatraz: The Whole Shocking Story_
and _The Night the Bridge Fell Down_ , and in the television movie
_Stormchasers: Revenge of the Twister_ (1998), with [Kelly
McGillis](/wiki/Kelly_McGillis "Kelly McGillis").

##
Semiretirement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=James_MacArthur&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Semiretirement")]

Throughout his career, MacArthur had also found time for various other
ventures. From 1959 to 1960, he partnered with actors [James
Franciscus](/wiki/James_Franciscus "James Franciscus") and [Alan Ladd,
Jr.](/wiki/Alan_Ladd,_Jr. "Alan Ladd, Jr.") in a Beverly Hills telephone
answering service. In June 1972, he directed the Honolulu Community Theatre in
a production of his father's play _[The Front Page](/wiki/The_Front_Page "The
Front Page")_. For a period in the 1990s, he was part owner of Senior World
publication, as well as writing the occasional celebrity interview. He
continued to appear at conventions, collectors' shows, and celebrity sporting
events. A keen golfer, he was the winner of the 2002 Frank Sinatra
Invitational Charity Golf Tournament.

He also appeared in television and radio specials and interview programs. His
latest appearances included spots on _Entertainment Tonight_ , _Christopher 's
Closeup_, and the [BBC Radio 5 Live](/wiki/BBC_Radio_5_Live "BBC Radio 5
Live") obituary program _Brief Lives_ , in which he paid tribute to his
_Hawaii Five-O_ castmate, the late [Kam Fong](/wiki/Kam_Fong_Chun "Kam Fong
Chun"). In 1997, MacArthur returned without Jack Lord (who was in declining
health) to reprise his character, who had become Hawaii's governor in the
plot, in the 1997 unaired pilot of _Hawaii Five-O_ which starred actor [Gary
Busey](/wiki/Gary_Busey "Gary Busey").

In April 2003, he traveled to Honolulu's historic Hawaii Theatre for a cameo
role in [Joe Moore](/wiki/Joe_Moore_\(television_journalist\) "Joe Moore
\(television journalist\)")'s play _Dirty Laundry_. Negotiations were underway
in summer 2010 for MacArthur to make a cameo appearance in the new CBS
primetime _[remake of Hawaii Five-O](/wiki/Hawaii_Five-0_\(2010_TV_series\)
"Hawaii Five-0 \(2010 TV series\)")_ at the time of his death, a role that
eventually was given to Al Harrington. On the November 1, 2010, episode,
MacArthur's death was mentioned in a short tribute that played before the
start of that episode.

In 2001, a Golden Palm Star on the [Palm Springs Walk of
Stars](/wiki/Palm_Springs_Walk_of_Stars "Palm Springs Walk of Stars") was
dedicated to him.[5]

## Death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=James_MacArthur&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Death")]

MacArthur died of cancer on October 28, 2010, at the age of 72, at the [Mayo
Clinic](/wiki/Mayo_Clinic "Mayo Clinic") in [Jacksonville,
Florida](/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida "Jacksonville, Florida"). At the time of
death, he was a resident of [Palm Desert,
California](/wiki/Palm_Desert,_California "Palm Desert, California"). He was
survived by his third wife, former [LPGA](/wiki/LPGA "LPGA") golfer Helen Beth
Duntz, of 25 years, and his four children: Charles P. MacArthur, Mary McClure,
Juliette Rappaport, and James D. MacArthur;[6] and seven grandchildren.[7][8]
His daughter Juliette was married to Beverly Hills real estate broker [Kurt
Rappaport](/wiki/Kurt_Rappaport "Kurt Rappaport").[6] He is interred in
[Nyack, New York](/wiki/Nyack,_New_York "Nyack, New York")'s Oak Hill
Cemetery.[9]

The episode "Ho'apono" from the 2010 version of _Hawaii Five-0_ was dedicated
to MacArthur.[10]
